facts.text: These appeals are directed against an order dated 9th March, 2007 passed by the High Court of Judicature, Andhra Pradesh at Hyderabad

anchor.surface_text: These appeals are directed against an order dated 9th March, 2007 passed by the High Court of Judicature, Andhra Pradesh at Hyderabad whereby the High Court has set aside the order passed by the State Administrate Tribunal in OA No.6334 of 1997 to the extent the same holds the judgment of this Court in V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors.  2001  10 SCC 401, to be prospective in its application.

facts.text: High Court set aside the order passed by the State Administrative Tribunal in OA No.6334 of 1997 to the extent it holds the judgment in V. Jagannadha Rao case prospective

anchor.surface_text: whereby the High Court has set aside the order passed by the State Administrate Tribunal in OA No.6334 of 1997 to the extent the same holds the judgment of this Court in V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors.  2001  10 SCC 401, to be prospective in its application.

facts.text: An order dated 3rd November, 2010 passed by the High Court dismissing a review petition filed by the appellants

anchor.surface_text: . An order dated 3rd November, 2010 passed by the High Court dismissing a review petition filed by the appellants against the said order has also been assailed.

facts.text: In V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors. 2001 10 SCC 401, a three-Judge Bench examined Special Rules framed by Governor under proviso to Article 309

anchor.surface_text: In V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors.  2001  10 SCC 401, a three-Judge Bench was examining whether Special Rules framed by the Governor of Andhra Pradesh under proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution to the extent the same permitted appointment by transfer to a higher category on the basis of seniority-cum-efficiency were violative of para 5 2  of the Presidential Order issued under Article 371-D of the Constitution of India, 1950.

facts.text: Presidential Order dated 18th October, 1975 issued under Article 371-D

anchor.surface_text: Answering the question in the affirmative this Court held that the Presidential Order dated 18th October, 1975 issued under Article 371-D of the Constitution was aimed at providing equitable opportunities and facilities to the people belonging to different parts of the State in the matter of public employment, education etc.

facts.text: GOMs No.72 dated 25th February, 1986 and GOMs No.117 dated 28th May, 1986 made UDCs in Labour Department and Factories and Boilers Department eligible for recruitment by transfer to Assistant Inspectors

anchor.surface_text: The question had arisen on account of a challenge mounted by the Ministerial employees of the Labour Department against GOMs No.72 dated 25th February, 1986 and GOMs No.117 dated 28th May, 1986 whereunder UDCs in the Labour Department and those working in Factories and Boilers Department were made eligible for recruitment by transfer to the posts of Assistant Inspectors of Labour and Assistant Inspectors of Factories.

facts.text: Full Bench of Tribunal declared impugned Rules violative of paras 3 and 5 of Presidential Order

anchor.surface_text: A full Bench of Tribunal before whom the challenge came up for consideration declared that the impugned Rules to the extent they enabled the Ministerial employees of the Factories and Boilers Department or any other department to be considered for appointment to the posts in the Labour Department were violative of paras 3 and 5 of the Presidential Order and hence void.

facts.text: Supreme Court in V. Jagannadha Rao dismissed appeals holding rules violative of Presidential Order

anchor.surface_text: Dismissing the appeals, this Court held that according to the scheme of the Presidential Order, local cadre was the unit under para 5 1  thereof for recruitment, appointment, seniority, promotion and transfers.

facts.text: Present cases relate to G.O.M. No.14 dated 26th November, 1994, amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996

anchor.surface_text: The current controversy does not relate to GOMs No.72 dated 25th February, 1986 and GOMs No.117 dated 28th May, 1986 which fell for consideration before this Court in V. Jagannadha Raos case  supra . The case at hand arises out of slightly different though essentially similar circumstances. The present batch of cases relates to G.O.M. No.14, Labour Employment Training  Ser. IV  Department, dated 26th November, 1994, as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996.

facts.text: G.O.Ms provide Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers in Head Offices eligible for appointment by transfer to Assistant Labour Officer

anchor.surface_text: These two G.O.Ms. provide that while Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Subordinate Offices of the Labour Department constitute the feeding channel under Rule 3 of Andhra Pradesh Labour Subordinate Service Rules, Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Head Offices shall also be eligible for appointment by transfer to the post of Assistant Labour Officer.

facts.text: Employees approached Andhra Pradesh Administrative Tribunal aggrieved by G.O.Ms

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the G.O.Ms. some of the employees approached the Andhra Pradesh Administrative Tribunal for redressal.

facts.text: Tribunal partly allowed petitions by order dated 7th March, 2003 striking down G.O.Ms to certain extent prospectively

anchor.surface_text: These petitions were partly allowed by the Tribunal in terms of its order dated 7th March, 2003 and G.O.M. No.14, dated 26th November, 1994, as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996 struck down as unconstitutional to the extent the same provided a channel for Senior Assistant and Senior Stenographer in Andhra Pradesh Ministerial Service working in the Head Offices of Labour Department and those in Factories and Boiler Departments besides those in the Subordinate Offices in the said Departments for appointment by transfer to the post of Assistant Labour Officer.

facts.text: Tribunal directed striking down prospective and no disturbance to actions till 7th November, 2001

anchor.surface_text: Having said that the Tribunal directed that the striking down of the impugned O.Ms. would only be prospective and that any action taken in compliance with the said Rules till 7th November, 2001 shall not be disturbed nor any employee promoted on the basis of the legal position that prevailed earlier to the decision of this Court in V. Jagannadha Raos case  supra  reverted.

facts.text: Writ Petitions No.6163 and 6068 of 2004 filed challenging Tribunal's prospective ruling

anchor.surface_text: The aggrieved employees, who had approached the Tribunal having succeeded but only in part, filed Writ Petitions No.6163 and 6068 of 2004 whereby they challenged the judgment of the Tribunal to the extent it saved the promotions already made on the basis of the impugned G.O.Ms.

facts.text: Writ Petition No.16890 of 2006 filed against Tribunal judgment by aggrieved employees

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petition No.16890 of 2006 was also filed against the very same judgment by some of the employees who felt aggrieved by the view taken by the Tribunal that the impugned G.O.Ms. were in violation of the Presidential Order hence unconstitutional.

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court allowed WP 6163 & 6068 of 2004, dismissed WP 16890 of 2006 on 9th March 2007

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh has, in terms of the judgment and order under challenge before us, allowed Writ Petitions No.6123 and 6068 of 2004 but dismissed Writ Petition No.16890 of 2006 relying upon certain decisions rendered by this Court.

facts.text: High Court held doctrine of prospective overruling only invocable by Supreme Court, not High Court

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has taken the view that the doctrine of prospective overruling could be invoked only by the Apex Court and not by other Court including High Courts exercising powers under Article 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellants filed Review WPMP No.3576 of 2010 aggrieved by High Court judgment

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in these appeals are employees who were not arrayed as parties to the writ petition filed before the High Court. Feeling aggrieved of the judgment and order passed by the High Court they filed Review WPMP No.3576 of 2010, inter alia, contending that the judgment under review had been passed without impleading employees like the appellants as parties to the case even though they were bound to be adversely affected by any modification that the High Court may have made.

facts.text: High Court dismissed review petitions on 3rd November 2010

anchor.surface_text: The review petitions were, accordingly, dismissed and the prayer for grant of leave to appeal to this Court rejected.

facts.text: OA No.6334 of 1997 filed before State Administrative Tribunal in 1997

anchor.surface_text: The petitions in the present case were filed before the State Administrative Tribunal in the year 1997.

facts.text: Tribunal order dated 27th March, 2003 struck down rules but saved promotions

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal had on the authority of the judgment aforementioned struck down the rules providing for ex-cadre zone promotions by its order dated 27th March, 2003, but saved the promotions already made.

facts.text: Promotions made before 7th November 2001 continued for nearly ten years

anchor.surface_text: Promotions made before the pronouncement of the order in Jagannadha Raos case  supra  i.e. before 7th November, 2001 have, thus, continued for nearly ten years till the review petition filed by the petitioners was dismissed and the matter brought up before this Court.

facts.text: State Government not willing to create supernumerary posts as per affidavit by Commissioner of Labour

anchor.surface_text: An additional affidavit filed by the Commissioner of Labour, Government of Andhra Pradesh, however, does not appear to be supportive of what could be a solution to the stalemate arising out of the impugned judgment. The affidavit states that there is no need to create supernumerary posts to accommodate the petitioners in their original posts i.e. Senior Assistants and senior stenographers.

facts.text: Petitioners promoted as Assistant Labour Officers, then to Assistant Commissioners or Deputy Commissioners

anchor.surface_text: Not only that, the incumbents who had been sent out on promotion as Assistant Labour Officers had subsequently been promoted as Assistant Labour Commissioners or Deputy Labour Commissioners.

facts.text: Appellants not arrayed as parties before Tribunal or High Court

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the petitioners were not arrayed as parties before the Tribunal or before the High Court also brings the fact situation of the present case closer to that in Kailash Chands case  supra .

issues.text: whether G.O.M. No.14 dated 26th November, 1994 as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996 providing eligibility for appointment by transfer to Assistant Labour Officer post from outside the zone violate paras 3(3) and 5(1) of the Presidential Order

anchor.surface_text: The present batch of cases relates to G.O.M. No.14, Labour Employment Training  Ser. IV  Department, dated 26th November, 1994, as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996. These two G.O.Ms. provide that while Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Subordinate Offices of the Labour Department constitute the feeding channel under Rule 3 of Andhra Pradesh Labour Subordinate Service Rules, Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Head Offices shall also be eligible for appointment by transfer to the post of Assistant Labour Officer.

issues.text: whether the doctrine of prospective overruling could be invoked only by the Apex Court and not by other Courts including High Courts exercising powers under Article 226 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has taken the view that the doctrine of prospective overruling could be invoked only by the Apex Court and not by other Court including High Courts exercising powers under Article 226 of the Constitution. The net effect of the view taken by the High Court, therefore, is that not only are the impugned G.O.M. held to be unconstitutional, but any action taken pursuant thereto is also declared to be unconstitutional.

issues.text: whether this Court should invoke the doctrine of prospective overruling to save promotions already made under the impugned G.O.Ms. prior to the judgment in V. Jagannadha Rao

anchor.surface_text: We have heard learned counsel for the parties at length. The doctrine of prospective overruling has its origin in American jurisprudence. It was first invoked in this country in C. Golak Nath Ors. v. State of Punjab Anr. AIR 1967 SC 1643...

arguments.claim: G.O.Ms No.14 and No.22 violate paras 3(3) and 5(1) of Presidential Order as they allow Senior Assistants and Stenographers from Head Offices and other departments outside the zone to be eligible for appointment by transfer to zonal post of Assistant Labour Officer

anchor.surface_text: These two G.O.Ms. provide that while Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Subordinate Offices of the Labour Department constitute the feeding channel under Rule 3 of Andhra Pradesh Labour Subordinate Service Rules, Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Head Offices shall also be eligible for appointment by transfer to the post of Assistant Labour Officer. Aggrieved by the G.O.Ms. some of the employees approached the Andhra Pradesh Administrative Tribunal for redressal. Their grievance primarily was that since the post of Assistant Labour Officer is a zonal post, employees working in the respective zones alone were entitled to be included in the feeding channel.

Feeling aggrieved of the judgment and order passed by the High Court they filed Review WPMP No.3576 of 2010, inter alia, contending that the judgment under review had been passed without impleading employees like the appellants as parties to the case even though they were bound to be adversely affected by any modification that the High Court may have made.

arguments.claim: Predominant legal opinion limits doctrine of prospective overruling to Supreme Court only; neither Tribunal nor High Court can invoke it

anchor.surface_text: There was some debate at the Bar whether the High Court could have invoked the doctrine of prospective overruling even if the State Administrative Tribunal was incompetent to do so. It was contended by the counsel appearing for the respondents that the predominant legal opinion emerging from the pronouncements of this Court limited the application of the doctrine of prospective overruling only by the Supreme Court.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: or phraseology. Each case needs examination in the light of its backdrop and the indelible effect of the decision. In the ultimate analysis, it is for

arguments.court_reasoning: Unnecessary to decide for High Court but Supreme Court agrees it has power under Art 142

arguments.claim: Supreme Court should invoke prospective overruling to save promotions as law in flux till V. Jagannadha Rao, long-held positions, reversion harsh and unfair

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Jayant Bhushan, learned senior counsel appearing on behalf of the respondent, on the other hand, argued and, in our opinion, rightly so that it was unnecessary for this Court to go into the question whether the doctrine of prospective overruling was available even to the High Court. He urged that there could be no manner of doubt that even if the High Court was not competent to invoke the doctrine, nothing prevented this Court from doing so having regard to the fact that those promoted under the impugned rules had held their respective positions for a considerable length of time making reversion to their parent zone cadre not only administratively difficult but unreasonably harsh and unfair.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: pressly enjoys that power under Article 142 of the Constitution which allows this Court to pass such decree or make such order as is necessary for doi

arguments.claim: No need to create supernumerary posts to accommodate petitioners as Senior Assistants/Stenographers or in higher posts

anchor.surface_text: An additional affidavit filed by the Commissioner of Labour, Government of Andhra Pradesh, however, does not appear to be supportive of what could be a solution to the stalemate arising out of the impugned judgment. The affidavit states that there is no need to create supernumerary posts to accommodate the petitioners in their original posts i.e. Senior Assistants and senior stenographers.

arguments.court_reasoning: Court notes unwillingness and proceeds to invoke doctrine instead

arguments.claim: Term 'transfer' in para 5(2) of Presidential Order does not include promotion as per scheme distinguishing transfer and promotion in para 5(1)

anchor.surface_text: No provision or word in a statute has to be read in isolation. In fact, the statute has to be read as a whole. A statute is an edict of the legislature. It cannot be said that without any purpose the distinction was made in para 5 1 between transfer and promotion and such distinction was not intended to be operative in para 5 2. The intention of the legislature is primarily to be gathered from the language used, which means that attention should be paid as to what has been said as also to what has not been said.

arguments.claim: Doctrine of prospective overruling should be invoked to save promotions made before 7th November 2001 as law in flux, parties not impleaded, long continuance, further promotions, cascading effect, equity

anchor.surface_text: Not only that, the incumbents who had been sent out on promotion as Assistant Labour Officers had subsequently been promoted as Assistant Labour Commissioners or Deputy Labour Commissioners. Such being the position reverting these officers at this distant point of time, to the posts of Senior Stenographers in their parent cadre does not appear to us to be either just, fair or equitable especially when upon reversion the State does not propose to promote them to the higher positions within their zone cadre because such higher posts are occupied by other officers, most if not all of whom are junior to the petitioners and who may have to be reverted to make room for the petitioners to hold those higher posts.

arguments.claim: V. Jagannadha Rao dealt with different GOMs (72,117) not current GOMs 14,22 so no impediment to prospective overruling here

anchor.surface_text: Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of terms comprising GoMs No.72 and 117 referred to earlier. While the basic question whether such GoMs permitting promotion by transfer from one department to the cadre or zone to another may have been the same, it cannot be denied that the rules with which this Court was concerned in Jagannadha Raos case supra were different from those with which we are dealing in the present case.

holdings.text: The doctrine of prospective overruling can be invoked by this Court in the instant case to save promotions made under the impugned rules prior to the judgment in V. Jagannadha Rao's case.

anchor.surface_text: Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Law was in state of flux until V. Jagannadha Rao clarified invalidity; promotions continued nearly 10 years with further promotions; reversion causes administrative chaos, cascading prejudice, unfairness; affected parties not impleaded; equity demands protection under Article 142 for complete justice.

holdings.text: It is unnecessary to decide whether the doctrine of prospective overruling was available to the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Jayant Bhushan, learned senior counsel appearing on behalf of the respondent, on the other hand, argued and, in our opinion, rightly so that it was unnecessary for this Court to go into the question whether the doctrine of prospective overruling was available even to the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court can invoke doctrine regardless; avoids deciding subordinate court power as this Court exercises it directly under Article 142.

holdings.text: The judgment in V. Jagannadha Rao's case does not stand as an impediment to applying the doctrine of prospective overruling in the present case as it dealt with different G.O.Ms.

anchor.surface_text: We feel that on the question of application of doctrine of prospective overruling, the judgment in Jagannadha Raos case supra will not stand as an impediment for this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: V. Jagannadha Rao concerned G.O.Ms. 72 and 117; present case involves different though similar G.O.Ms. 14 and 22; no bar to new application of doctrine.

holdings.text: The Supreme Court possesses power under Article 142 to invoke prospective overruling and mould relief for complete justice.

anchor.surface_text: As a matter of fact Articles 32 4 and 142 are designed with words of width to enable the Supreme Court to declare the law and to give such directions or pass such orders as are necessary to do complete justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 142 confers constituent power with width and elasticity to meet situations, declare law prospectively, adjust rights, prevent injustice; supported by precedents like Golak Nath, Ashok Kumar Gupta, Somaiya Organics.

precedents.citation: V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors.  2001  10 SCC 401

anchor.surface_text: Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. outcome.relief_summary: Doctrine of prospective overruling invoked to save past promotions made before 7th November 2001; no reversion or disturbance of actions taken pursuant to impugned GOMs prior to V. Jagannadha Rao judgment

Reversion held unjust, unfair and inequitable
No creation of supernumerary posts needed as promotions protected prospectively

Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case.
